title: LR circuit - potential diff after opening switch

content.question: A battery of <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> <math alttext="open E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>, switch, resistor <math alttext="R sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>R</mtext><mtext>1</mtext></msub></math> of resistance <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, resistor <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>R</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> of resistance <math alttext="2 R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>R</mi></math>, and inductor of inductance <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math> are connected as shown in the circuit diagram. The switch is closed and remains closed for a long time. Immediately after the switch is opened, the electric potential difference across the inductor is equal to <math alttext="2 open E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>. Which of the following provides a correct description of why the potential difference across the inductor is twice the potential difference of the battery?

choices.label: The current in the inductor must remain the same immediately before and after the switch is opened because of conservation of charge. Because the resistor in the loop with the inductor is <math alttext="2 R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>R</mi></math>, the potential difference across the inductor must be <math alttext="2 open E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>.

The potential difference across the inductor increases over time when the switch is closed. When the switch is opened, the potential difference is released through Resistor <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>R</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math>. Because the resistance of <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>R</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> is twice the resistance of <math alttext="R sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>R</mtext><mtext>1</mtext></msub></math>, the potential difference across the inductor is twice the potential difference of the battery.

When the switch has been closed for a long time, the current from the circuit is stored in the inductor. When the switch is opened, the stored current is released through Resistor <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>R</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math>. For the current to be the same, the potential difference of the inductor must be twice the potential difference of the battery.

The charge in the inductor increases over time. It becomes fully charged when the switch is closed for a long time. After the switch is opened, the stored charged is discharged through Resistor <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>R</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math>. Because the resistance of <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>R</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> is twice the resistance of <math alttext="R sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>R</mtext><mtext>1</mtext></msub></math>, the potential difference of the inductor is twice the potential difference of the battery.

content.answer: The current in the inductor must remain the same immediately before and after the switch is opened because of conservation of charge. Because the resistor in the loop with the inductor is <math alttext="2 R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>R</mi></math>, the potential difference across the inductor must be <math alttext="2 open E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>.
